description: From 19th-century British thieves' cant, of uncertain origin. Sense of nonsense possibly influenced by tush (“nonsense! tsk tsk!”) attested from 15th century.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, Britain, slang, obsolete) Copper; items made of copper.
(uncountable, chiefly Britain, slang, rare) Valuables retrieved from drains and sewers.
examples: I am present engaged in fishing for tosh in the sewers of Blastburn.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain, slang, uncountable) Rubbish, trash, (now especially) nonsense, bosh, balderdash
(UK, archaic school slang, countable) A bath or foot pan

examples: Among the recent neologisms of the cricket field is ‘tosh’, which means bowling of contemptible easiness.

entries.meaning: (UK, humorous slang, uncountable) Used as a form of address.

verbs.description: tosh (third-person singular simple present toshes, present participle toshing, simple past and past participle toshed)

entries.meaning: (Britain, obsolete slang) To steal copper, particularly from ship hulls
(chiefly Britain, uncommon slang) To search for valuables in sewers
examples: You tend to the toshing, let Mester Hobday tend to the dealing.

entries.meaning: (UK, archaic school slang) To use a tosh-pan, either to wash, to splash, or to "bath"
examples: ‘Toshing’ was the name given to a punishment inflicted by the cadets on any one of their number who made himself obnoxious. The victim, dressed in full uniform, was forced to run the gauntlet of his brother cadets, who, as he passed, emptied the contents of their ‘tosh-cans’ (small baths holding about three gallons of water) over the wretched lad's head.

description: Compare Old French tonce (“shorn, clipped”) and English tonsure.

examples: I gang ay fou clean and fou tosh
As a' the neighbours can tell.
We were a very tosh and agreeable company.

adverbs.description: tosh (comparative more tosh, superlative most tosh)

examples: Shouther your arms!—O! had them tosh on, And not athraw!

verbs.description: tosh (third-person singular simple present toshes, present participle toshing, simple past and past participle toshed)

entries.meaning: (Scotland) To make ‘tosh’: to tidy, to trim.
examples: Hoo she wad try to tosh up... her breest.

description: From 19th-century British slang tosheroon, from or alongside tusheroon, of uncertain derivation from British slang caroon (“crown, a 5-shilling silver coin”), from Sabir and (originally) Italian corona (“crown”). The term was either derived from or influenced by madza caroon, the British slang for the Sabir and Italian mezzo corona (“half-crown”), possibly under influence from tosh (“copper items; valuables”) above or from the half-crown's value of two shillings & sixpence.

entries.meaning: (Britain, obsolete slang, countable) A half-crown coin; its value
examples: Here's a tosh to buy yourself some beer.

entries.meaning: (Britain, obsolete slang, countable) A crown coin; its value
examples: Half-a-crown is known as an alderman, half a bull, half a tusheroon, and a madza caroon; whilst a crown piece, or five shillings, may be called either a bull, or a caroon, or a cartwheel, or a coachwheel, or a thick-un, or a tusheroon.

entries.meaning: (Britain, archaic slang, uncountable) Any money, particularly pre-decimalization British coinage
